3.40.text: Enchanted Dreams at Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery

6.40.text: is the first ever retrospective of the British artist Edward Robert Hughes.

11.17.text: It brings together paintings, drawings, watercolours, prints and photographs

15.70.text: on loan from public and private collections in the UK and overseas.

20.08.text: Many of them haven't been seen in the 100 years since Hughes died in 1914.

26.66.text: Enchanted Dreams takes visitors on a journey through Hughes' life and art.

30.93.text: From his Pre-Raphaelite childhood in the 1850s

33.86.text: to the late symbolist watercolours like Night with her Train of Stars

37.18.text: that he exhibited just before the First World War.

42.48.text: E.R. Hughes grew up among the radical Pre-Raphaelite group of artists.

47.64.text: His uncle was the artist Arthur Hughes.

50.31.text: Who painted one of Birmingham's most famous Pre-Raphaelite works

56.36.text: The young Hughes was remembered by his family

58.48.text: as a handsome, loving, brilliant boy, wild for painting.

63.19.text: it was his uncle Arthur who encouraged his artistic talent

66.19.text: and gave him his first lessons in painting.

69.86.text: After studying at Heatherley School of Art in London

73.90.text: Hughes established himself as an artist in the 1870s.

78.40.text: Initially he was best known for his portraits,

81.14.text: a range of which can be seen in the exhibition.

85.73.text: for his sensitive and perspective images of children.

91.03.text: are two portraits of Hughes niece Dolly, painted 1887,

95.59.text: which have never been exhibited before.

98.47.text: The drawing in red chalk was made in preparation

101.55.text: for the final version in oil which hangs alongside.

105.59.text: Hughes kept the portrait until 1911 when Dolly got engaged

109.32.text: and gave it to her as a wedding present.

111.90.text:
He wrote to her:
'Nobody but you should have it. I like it myself too well'.

117.32.text: During his own lifetime Hughes was often more admired

120.05.text: for his drawings than for his paintings.

125.43.text: especially working in red and black chalk

127.61.text: and in coloured chalks and pastel.

131.19.text: The exhibition brings together a range of the drawings that Hughes exhibited in London

135.32.text: at the Royal Watercolour Society's exhibition of sketches and studies.

139.58.text: They include portraits of friends, family and fellow artists

147.17.text: All of them share Hughes' mastery of drawing technique

152.13.text: Hughes often exhibited at the Royal Watercolour Society.

155.20.text: Where he showed large scale elaborate watercolours

162.11.text: and Italian Medieval and Renaissance tales.

165.96.text: A highlight of the exhibition is the haunting and macabre watercolour

171.36.text: inspired by Christina Rossetti's poem Amor Mundi or Earthly Love.

175.87.text: It shows a gaunt, bony, dead body

178.35.text: lying in a hollow and surrounded by wild roses

181.27.text: which twine around and enclose it.

185.07.text: The exhibition ends with a room dedicated to what one critic called

188.20.text: 'Those harmonies of deep, luminous blues of which Hughes seems to have the secret'.

194.88.text: At the heart of the exhibition is Night with her Train of Stars

198.12.text: which was given to the city of Birmingham in Hughes' memory

200.82.text: by his friends and family after his death.

204.56.text: Night with her Train of Stars

206.32.text: shows the gentle, serene and reassuring figure of night .

209.49.text: Floating through a glowing sky flecked with gold.

212.25.text: Cradling a child in her arms

214.09.text: and followed by jostling, lively cupids

220.06.text: The final room of the exhibition also includes Midsummer Eve.

223.51.text: Which has become one Hughes most famous works

226.30.text: even though it is rarely seen in museums and galleries

228.85.text: and it has been in a series of private collections since it was painted in 1908.

233.69.text: It has become famous world wide through being reproduced

236.64.text: on posters, calenders, cards and on the internet.

240.48.text: But Enchanted Dreams offers a unique opportunity

243.35.text: to experience its subtly and beauty in the original.

247.85.text: Enchanted Dreams runs at Birmingham and Museum and Art Gallery
